concepts.definition: The square root of the variance, measuring the average distance of data points from the mean.
concepts.explanation: Standard deviation quantifies data spread and is used in risk analysis, finance, and quality control.

concepts.definition: The arithmetic average of a set of values.
concepts.explanation: The mean summarizes the central tendency of data and is foundational in statistics and data science.

concepts.definition: The middle value in a sorted list of numbers.
concepts.explanation: Median is robust to outliers and is used in descriptive statistics and analytics.

concepts.definition: The value that appears most frequently in a data set.
concepts.explanation: Mode is useful for categorical data and understanding data distributions.

concepts.definition: The difference between the largest and smallest values in a data set.
concepts.explanation: Range provides a simple measure of data spread.

concepts.definition: The difference between the 75th and 25th percentiles (Q3 - Q1) in a data set.
concepts.explanation: IQR measures statistical dispersion and is less sensitive to outliers than range.

concepts.definition: Values that divide a data set into four equal parts.
concepts.explanation: Quartiles help summarize data distribution and are used in box plots.

concepts.definition: Values below which a certain percentage of data falls.
concepts.syntax: Pth percentile: value below which P% of data falls
examples: 90th percentile: score higher than 90% of data
concepts.explanation: Percentiles are used in standardized testing, analytics, and risk assessment.

concepts.definition: A summary of a data set: minimum, Q1, median, Q3, maximum.
concepts.explanation: Five number summary is used in box plots and exploratory data analysis.

concepts.definition: A graphical representation of the five number summary and outliers.
concepts.syntax: Box from Q1 to Q3, line at median, whiskers to min/max
examples: Box plot shows spread and outliers for exam scores
concepts.explanation: Box plots are used for visualizing data distribution and identifying outliers.

concepts.definition: A bar graph representing the frequency distribution of a data set.
examples: Histogram of ages in a survey
concepts.explanation: Histograms show the shape and spread of data distributions.

concepts.definition: A measure of the asymmetry of a data distribution.
concepts.syntax: Positive skew: tail right; Negative skew: tail left
examples: Income data often has positive skew
concepts.explanation: Skewness helps understand data distribution and outliers.

concepts.definition: A measure of the 'tailedness' of a data distribution.
concepts.syntax: High kurtosis: heavy tails; Low kurtosis: light tails
concepts.explanation: Kurtosis helps assess risk and outliers in data.

concepts.definition: A measure of the linear relationship between two variables.
examples: Height and weight have positive correlation
concepts.explanation: Correlation is used in regression, finance, and feature selection.

concepts.definition: A measure of how two variables change together.
concepts.explanation: Covariance is used in portfolio theory and statistics.

concepts.definition: A subset of a population used to estimate characteristics of the whole.
concepts.explanation: Sampling is essential for inference and reducing data collection costs.

concepts.definition: The entire group of individuals or items being studied.
concepts.syntax: All members of a defined group
concepts.explanation: Population parameters are estimated using samples.

concepts.definition: Techniques for selecting a sample from a population (random, stratified, cluster, etc.).
examples: Random sampling: every member has equal chance
concepts.explanation: Sampling methods affect bias and accuracy of statistical inference.

concepts.definition: A numerical value summarizing a characteristic of a population.
concepts.explanation: Parameters are estimated from samples in inferential statistics.

concepts.definition: A numerical value summarizing a characteristic of a sample.
concepts.syntax: Sample mean x̄, sample std dev s
concepts.explanation: Statistics are used to estimate population parameters.

concepts.definition: A systematic error that leads to incorrect estimates of population parameters.
examples: Surveying only morning commuters introduces bias
concepts.explanation: Bias reduces accuracy and validity of statistical conclusions.

concepts.definition: A rule or formula for calculating an estimate of a population parameter from sample data.
concepts.syntax: x̄ estimates μ, s^2 estimates σ^2
examples: Sample mean as an estimator for population mean
concepts.explanation: Estimators are central to inferential statistics.

concepts.definition: The theorem stating that the sampling distribution of the sample mean approaches a normal distribution as sample size increases.
examples: Means of large samples from any distribution are approximately normal
concepts.explanation: The CLT justifies using normal approximations in inference.

concepts.definition: The principle that as the size of a sample increases, its mean gets closer to the population mean.
examples: Flipping a coin many times approaches 50% heads
concepts.explanation: This law underpins statistical inference and reliability.

concepts.definition: A statistical method for making decisions about population parameters based on sample data.
concepts.syntax: State H0 and H1, compute test statistic, compare to threshold
examples: Testing if a new drug is effective
concepts.explanation: Hypothesis testing is used for scientific and business decision making.

concepts.definition: The default assumption that there is no effect or difference.
examples: H0: new treatment has no effect
concepts.explanation: The null hypothesis is tested against the alternative hypothesis in inference.

concepts.definition: The hypothesis that there is an effect or difference, opposite to the null hypothesis.
concepts.explanation: The alternative hypothesis is accepted if the null is rejected.

concepts.definition: The probability of obtaining results at least as extreme as the observed results, assuming the null hypothesis is true.
concepts.explanation: p-values are used to decide whether to reject the null hypothesis.

concepts.definition: A threshold probability (α) below which the null hypothesis is rejected.
examples: If p < 0.05, reject H0 at 5% significance
concepts.explanation: Significance levels control the likelihood of Type I error.

concepts.definition: Incorrectly rejecting the null hypothesis when it is actually true (false positive).
examples: Concluding a drug works when it doesn't
concepts.explanation: Type I error is controlled by the significance level.

concepts.definition: Failing to reject the null hypothesis when it is actually false (false negative).
examples: Missing a real effect of a new drug
concepts.explanation: Type II error is related to the power of a test.

concepts.definition: The probability of correctly rejecting the null hypothesis when it is false.
examples: A test with 80% power detects a true effect 80% of the time
concepts.explanation: High power reduces Type II errors and is desirable in hypothesis testing.

concepts.definition: A range of values, derived from sample data, that is likely to contain the true population parameter.
concepts.explanation: Confidence intervals quantify uncertainty in parameter estimates.

concepts.definition: The number of standard deviations a data point is from the mean.
concepts.explanation: Z-scores standardize data and are used in hypothesis testing and normal distributions.

concepts.definition: A standardized score used in t-distributions, often for small samples.
concepts.explanation: T-scores are used when population standard deviation is unknown.

concepts.definition: A probability distribution used to estimate population parameters when sample size is small and/or variance is unknown.
examples: Used in t-tests for small sample means
concepts.explanation: The t-distribution is wider than the normal distribution and is used in inference with small samples.
